content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, given my risk-taking nature and the desire to maximize earnings, I would choose a strategy that aims for the highest possible average payoff over the 75 rounds.

In this game, picking R provides a higher payoff (45$) than picking B (12$ or 42$, depending on the opponent's choice) when the opponent also picks R. However, if the opponent consistently picks R, I would benefit more from occasionally switching to B (to receive 42$ instead of 0$).

If we assume that the opponent is rational and will try to maximize their earnings as well, there are two possible scenarios:

1) The opponent always picks R. In this case, my optimal strategy would be to pick R in some rounds (to gain 45$) and switch to B in other rounds (to avoid losing money). This would result in an average payoff of 27$ per round ([R] for the rounds I pick R, and [B] for the rounds I pick B, resulting in a mix of 27$ and 12$ earnings).

2) The opponent always picks B. In this case, my optimal strategy would be to pick R in every round, as picking B results in a loss (0$) when the opponent also picks R. This would result in an average payoff of 30$ per round ([R] in all rounds).

Since a rational opponent would likely follow either scenario 1 or 2, the strategy that guarantees the highest average payoff is to pick R in every round ([R]). However, since it's impossible to know for certain whether the opponent will follow a specific strategy, I might choose B in a few rounds to minimize potential losses due to an opponent following scenario 1. Nevertheless, my primary strategy would be to stick with R ([R]).
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since my opponent also picked R in the previous round, I will pick B in the next round to minimize potential losses from sticking with R and having my opponent continue picking R (as in scenario 1 described earlier).

So, for the next round, my choice is [B]. However, it's important to note that this is a one-time deviation from my primary strategy of picking R due to the specific outcome of the previous round. I would expect the opponent to notice this change in my strategy and potentially adjust their own choices accordingly in future rounds.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

Given that both me and my opponent picked B in the previous round, I will stick with R in the next round to maximize potential earnings (45$ if my opponent also picks R).

So, for the next round, my choice is [R]. However, it's important to keep in mind that switching strategies can sometimes be beneficial as well, especially when dealing with an unknown or adaptive opponent. In this case, I might consider switching back to B after a few rounds of playing R if I notice that my opponent consistently picks R as well. But for now, I will stick with R ([R]).
